TF034856-HAITI - ROAD MAINTENANCE AND
            REHABILITATION PROJECT,TF033950-HAITI - ROAD MAINTENANCE AND REHABILITATION

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is highly
            unsatisfactory, sustainability unlikely, with negligible
            institutional development impacts. Similarly, ratings on
            Bank performance reflect unsatisfactory results, largely due
            to inadequacies in the initial project design in addressing
            institutional constraints, and the weak supervision of
            project activities, while the Borrower's performance
            reflects highly unsatisfactory ratings, based on numerous
            difficulties encountered during implementation. Lessons
            first address the need to balance implementation, sector
            objectives, and social impacts, particularly under
            post-conflict situations where important trade-offs among
            these three aspects in project design, and intervention
            readiness, means understanding the related costs and
            benefits, and mitigation risks. Second, in the absence of
            governance and institutional framework, it is necessary to
            rely on well-defined implementation shortcuts that bypass
            traditional government channels, but tailored to
            implementation capacity. This leads to the need to
            reformulate managerial, and administrative practices for
            asset management, to maximize existing capabilities, ensure
            greater transparency, while allowing tighter monitoring, and
            supervisory criteria. In addition, the need to improve aid
            coordination, specifically in project design for roads,
            should incorporate an integrated approach, that focuses on
            economic, and social priorities.
